CME Group ยักษ์ใหญ่วอลล์สตรีตพิจารณาออกโทเคนของตัวเอง CEO บอก

Wall Street Titan CME Group Is Considering Issuing Its Own Token, CEO Reveals

1d ago//Brenda Ngari
general
AI

Summary

TH

CME Group CEO Terry Duffy เปิดเผยว่าตลาดซื้อขาย derivatives ที่ใหญ่ที่สุดในโลกกำลังสำรวจความเป็นไปได้ในการเปิดตัว Token ของตัวเองบน Decentralized network ในระหว่างการประชุม Q4 earnings call ผู้บริหารได้หารือเกี่ยวกับ Tokenized collateral โดยแสดงความเชื่อมั่นใน Token ที่ออกโดยสถาบันการเงินที่สำคัญมากกว่าธนาคารขนาดเล็ก การเคลื่อนไหวนี้สอดคล้องกับกลยุทธ์ Crypto ที่กว้างขวางขึ้นของ CME ซึ่งรวมถึงโครงการ Tokenized cash แยกต่างหากกับ Google, สัญญา Futures ใหม่สำหรับ Cardano, Stellar และ Chainlink และแผนการเปิดให้ซื้อขาย Crypto แบบ 24/7 ภายในไตรมาสที่สองของปี 2026

EN

CME Group CEO Terry Duffy revealed that the world’s largest derivatives exchange is actively exploring the launch of its own token on a decentralized network. During the Q4 earnings call, Duffy discussed tokenized collateral and expressed a preference for tokens issued by systemically important financial institutions over smaller banks. This move complements CME's broader crypto strategy, which includes a separate tokenized cash initiative with Google, new futures contracts for Cardano, Stellar, and Chainlink, and plans to introduce 24/7 crypto trading by the second quarter of 2026.

Key Points

  • CME Group is exploring launching its own token on a decentralized network.
  • CEO Terry Duffy prefers tokens from systemically important financial institutions for margin.
  • CME is expanding crypto products with futures for Cardano, Stellar, and Chainlink, and plans for 24/7 trading in 2026.

Article

CME Group CEO Terry Duffy has revealed that the world’s largest derivatives exchange is actively exploring the possibility of launching its own cryptocurrency. CME Coin In response to a question from Morgan Stanley’s Michael Cyprys during CME’s Q4 earnings call on Wednesday, Duffy confirmed the company is exploring “initiatives with our own coin that we could potentially put on a decentralized network.” “Not only are we looking at tokenized cash […] we’re looking at different initiatives with our own coin that we could potentially put on a decentralized network for other of our industry participants to use,” he posited. The remark came in response to a question about the role of tokenized collateral. In response, Duffy first noted that the derivatives behemoth is meticulously examining various forms of margin. “So if you were to give me a token from a systemically important financial institution, I would probably be more comfortable than maybe a third or fourth-tier bank trying to issue a token for margin.” Advertisement CME is already working on a tokenized cash “initiative” that’s being rolled out with Google later this year, which will involve a depository bank enabling transactions. The potential CME-issued token running on a decentralized, public network would be a separate project, though the exchange declined to specify how it would function. Nonetheless, CEO Duffy’s remarks this week mark the first time the exchange has explicitly floated the launch of its own digital token. Still, a potential debut wouldn’t make CME the first legacy finance titan to issue its own token. JPMorgan recently introduced tokenized deposits on Coinbase’s Base layer-2 blockchain via its JPM Coin. CME’s 24/7 Trading Push The revelation comes as CME Group continues to extend its crypto footprint. In January, CME announced plans to expand its suite of crypto products by listing futures contracts tied to Cardano, Stellar, and Chainlink this month for both retail and institutional traders. Meanwhile, the exchange is set to introduce 24/7 trading for cryptocurrency futures and options beginning in the second quarter of 2026, pending regulatory approval. The move aims to align CME’s products more closely with around-the-clock digital asset markets.
